text: Miss Doris Butt, assistant to Mr. Caldecott, of the Long Twizzle, Dorsetshire Fuel Control Office, is leaving her employ. She is telling her successor what a sunshine she has been to the firm and the customers, what a loss it's going to be to the firm, her going - still, the King and country needed her.

title-link: Amo, Amas, Amat, Amamus, Amatis, Enough!
text: Truth is a wood violet that blooms in the least likely corner, and I found it in a couple of obscure pulp magazines called Gay Love Stories and Ideal Love... Excerpts and comment.

title-link: Something for a man in his forties
text: Millie Sanders and her friend Elise Adams go shopping for a present for Mr. Sanders. Mrs. Sanders had received a bonus check for fifty dollars, which was the amount she planned to spend for the present. Arriving at the store, she saw a bag she liked and bought it for herself. That took twelve-fifty out of the fifty dollars. When the ladies finally found something they thought Mr. Sanders would like, the price of it was fifty. Mrs. Sanders paid a deposit, returned the bag, and paid for the present.

title-link: Well, Roll Me In A Turkish Towel!
text: Biography of an old sweatshirt inspired by reading the biography of a little sweater, made by the Irwill Knitting Corporation.

Tells about the explosion of Professor Shoreham. The proprietor of the Gourmet Restaurant and Oyster Bar, Nick Popolus, could only tell the newspaperman that the explosion which wrecked his restaurant, was caused by Professor Shoreham who had exploded while having his lunch there.
A charting of some of the notches which civilians have been asked to take in their belts during this war without causing anyone to feel the slightest pain.

title-link: V Is For A Lot Of Things
text: Mrs. Buell discharged her Sicilian gardener, who had been with her for ten years, when he told her that he was not a citizen. When his oldest son was drafted she thought he would do something about it. She started a garden herself. One day he dropped around to inspect it. He still wasn't a citizen, but he knew how to set her garden right.
An emergency operation performed at sea.

In order to save gas author combines a number of errands; picking up a load of hens from the station; arranging to interview prospective cooks, etc. The cooks didn't show up but one of the hens laid an egg.

Mrs. Blessure was a rich woman who was distressed by the war and the impending class struggle. She decided to retire to the country. She bought a house in a rural, backward area of Pennsylvania, where the people were ignorant & superstitious. Simon, her gardener, thought she was a witch. She gave him some little colored sponges to give to his small boy, which he did. That same night Simon's wife accidentally scalded herself & the child. She believed it was due to a spell cast by Mrs. Blessure. One day Mrs Blessure came to Simon's house to fetch him. Simon's wife murdered her, threw the body in a canal, where it was not discovered until a year later, and the death remained a mystery.
Deaf and dumb pupils at F. Knapp's Institute in Baltimore.

Mrs. Noble was in a restaurant waiting for ther daughter in-law, who was going to lunch with her. The waitress complimented Mrs. Noble on her youthful appearance. Gratified, Mrs. Noble said she was proud of having a son in the Navy, and a grandson six years old. She asked the waitress to be on the look-out for her daughter-in-law. The girl said she'd recognize her- she used to be a model To which Mrs. Noble replied that that was eight years ago When the daughter-in-law arrived, they chatted about what they were doing. She said she didn't have enough to do, and was thinking of going back to her job, if Mrs. Noble would let her little boy spend a few hours a day at her house. Mrs. Noble said no, she needed a rest after working with Red Cross four hours aday, and the maid had too much to do. She couldn't understand how the girl could have lost her sense of proportion to that extent.

Description of Dorothy Stickney's new hat. It was designed by Mme. Lilly Dache with the advice and consent of the Garden Club of America and it contains forty-three kinds of flowers and enough lover's-knots to baste up several brace of good husky lovers. It consumes a gill of dew each morning.

A married man is left alone in town when his wife takes her yearly jaunt to Atlantic City. Since his wife had urged him to seek feminine companionship while she was away he decided to look up an old friend of his. He and Chloe (the girl) spent a long and expensive evening, stopping first for drinks, then dinner, and afterwards at a night club. He was seen by numerous friends - and he was properly punished by his wife upon her return.

Husband makes a remark about a radio program he is listening to. His wife who has been reading asked him what was on the program. He got sore, she had the radio on all day long but she never listened to it... She said if her radio habits were to be questioned she'd prefer to have it done by Crossley, though she couldn't understand how they took their poll. She had never heard of anybody they had ever asked. The husband tried to explain how it was done, but she knew he didn't know it himself and she told him so. One thing led to another, a friend's name was brought up and he accused her of running around with the man. It all ended by him slapping her face.
Convoy bound for North Africa describes air attacks.

Busdriver teases a young girl, an early morning passenger. One morning he went a little too far and she got angry. He apologized and she left him with a smile. For the next few days there were no more trick, but warm smiles passed between them. In a few weeks they knew all they had to know about each other to fall in love, and after the period of unconscious caution it became a case of who would make the first move. He did. She knew that he was married. He now told her that he hated his wife. He was too much in love with her to keep his route and had asked to be transferred.
Description of a journey on the Corsican express and a visit to the home of the only direct descendant of Christopher Columbus.

A very young British soldier got on a crowded Madison Ave. bus in a pouring rain. He asked an American soldier and his wife to tell him when they got to 68th St. They promised to look out for him. Something that had happened that afternoon struck them very funny and they began to laugh. They couldn't let him in on the joke, and when they reached 68th St. they told him it was his stop. He must have heard them laughing as the doors closed. Suddenly the soldier remembered that it was a west side address the kid wanted, but it was too late to do anything about it. They realized the boy must have thought it a very poor joke.

A young girl flagged a bus at 6th Ave. and 10th St. & asked the driver if he could get her to 44 St. in ten minutes. The driver said he couldn't take the bus. A passenger made the remark to the driver that it was a hot one; and they made conjectures as to what could be her hurry - meeting a boy friend undoubtedly. Then they discussed the possibility of making the trip in ten minutes The driver said that he could do it by passing a few stops and driving through a few lights at the risk of his job, of course. As they passed 44th St. the driver slower down and both men stared out the window carefully. They expected to see the girl there standing talking to somebody, possibly a soldier. . .
